Court papers say Kozel overpaid by more than $2.55 million, then had the excess money funneled to accounts held by him and his second wife, Inga, in Lithuania.

BE11:21am

The gist here is that retail's on 2007 valuations and there's pockets of value among the biggest fallers.

BE11:21am

 Sporting Goods offers structural growth and is taking share from conventional
apparel retail
 Peak fast fashion? Millennials/Gen X have less money and spend it differently
 High market shares in apparel are hard to sustain as markets fragment, but hardlines will
continue to consolidate
 . Sears and HoF both rescued
 Online channel shift may accelerate as retail options reduce
 Multi-channel retailing is hard and almost always dilutive to margins and returns
 Brands still need third party distribution and there are very few high quality routes to
market (Asos, Zalando, JD have some pricing power)
 It’s currently a buyers’ market for apparel, although favourable FX will roll off over
next 6-12 months
 Demand for discount formats will continue to grow, but access and footfall are
critical
 Consolidation plays can be volatile as peers fail

11:21 am
BE11:21am

So .....

BE11:21am

We still see structural L-T sales growth in sporting goods (Adidas/JD Sport), discount
(B&M/Primark/ABF) and online (Asos/Zalando).

Fresnillo PLC (FRES:LSE): Last: 913.80, up 38.6 (+4.41%), High: 915.00, Low: 884.00, Volume: 308.88k
BE11:27am

Merrill, Goldman and Credit Suisse.

BE11:28am

We run scenarios to asses commodity price levels reflected in current "Big Miner" share prices. A commodity deck -25% vs. spot yields EV/EBITDA for the Big 4 of c. 8-9x, consistent with trough. valuations. Compelling- Lower prices based on expectations of China hard landing = lower EBITDA / higher mults. But hard landing not our base case...

11:28 am
BE11:28am

That's the Merrill summary.

BE11:29am

And Goldman ....

BE11:30am

The rhetoric and
the announcements from the Chinese policymakers have started to turn positive
with the govt. announcing a number of measures.
n RRR cut: Policymakers on Friday announced a 1pp cut in RRR. This was followed
by President Li’s comment that both general and targeted RRR cuts need to be
implemented appropriately.
n Shift in monetary policy description: Also important to note is the shift in the
official monetary policy description at the December Central Economic Work
Conference, from “prudent and neutral” to “prudent with appropriate looseness
and tightness”. The new description is similar to what was adopted in 2015, when
monetary policy eased significantly (see chart below)
n Fiscal policy: More proactive fiscal policy as the Chinese govt. is looking to
increase the size of local govt. special purpose bond issuances meaningfully. The
govt. in December passed a bill which allowed local govt. to issue 1.39 tb yuan
worth of bonds before the legislature officially approved a 2019 quota — this is
equal to 64% of the 2018 quota (Caixin).
n Infrastructure property announcements: China announced that it will expand
its high-speed rail network by 3200Km — a 45% increase in expansion from 2018. This comes after FAI slowed to a decade-low of 5.9% in first 11 months of
2018. Also, there have been some announcements around property with Hangzhou
and Zhuhai announcing loosening measures in December.
News flow around trade talks has been supportive and the Fed is likely to be more
data-dependent which our economists believe is likely to lead to a softer dollar.
n Trade talks moving in right direction: The rhetoric around trade talks has turned
slightly positive with President Trump saying that the talks with China are moving in
the right direction with a lot of progress being made(WSJ). The second round of
talks between the US and China is slated to begin today.
n Softer dollar: Our economists have turned bearish on USD after the recent spate of
weak US data, most notably the ISM manufacturing data. This comes after Fed chair
emphasized the Fed’s flexibility and willingness to be “patient,” highlighting the
Fed’s pause through most of 2016 as an example of this data-dependent approach.
On miners - we believe the key argument is around the growth levels in 2019. While 1Q
 1H is expected to be weak - as highlighted by our commodities team, they remain
fairly positive on commodity demand, especially on the back of recent
growth-supporting measures by the Chinese policymakers. While they have taken their
NT prices lower - they maintain their bullish view. This, coupled with the fact that the
miners (esp. the Big 4) have strong balance sheets, and are generating double digit free
cash flows (on spot / GSe) makes us relatively positive on miners.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

And have Citi as well, since we're filling time.

BE11:31am

Historically in market sell-offs it has paid to avoid the miners as they
have sold off much more heavily than the market. The miners have historically
demonstrated a higher down beta than up beta, i.e. they fell much more in a falling
market then they gained in a rising market. However this appears to be reversing
with not only the absolute beta coming down relative to the market, but also the
down beta has fallen dramatically. In other words, the moves to the downside are
being cushioned; arguably this is a direct outcome of the improved balance sheets
of the mining companies and/or higher margins. In the recent market sell-off in Q4
2018 the miners fell only slightly more than the market. We think this theme can
continue to play out in 2019 despite the miners being very sensitive to macro growth
- the Enterprise Value has now been accruing to shareholders (debt to equity) which
is expected to lift the floor of the mining companies and reduce investor risk.
Furthermore beta has moved down significantly in the past year. One of our key
views for the mining sector is that we expect that the beta of the mining companies
to move down, thereby reducing the WACC of the mining companies and potentially
result in a sector re-rating.

Penny DT / BT ?
BE11:38am

The acquisition would be the largest and latest in a series of transactions Lilly has conducted to broaden its cancer treatment efforts with externally sourced opportunities for first-in-class and best-in-class therapies. Loxo Oncology is developing a pipeline of targeted medicines focused on cancers that are uniquely dependent on single gene abnormalities that can be detected by genomic testing. For patients with cancers that harbor these genomic alterations, a targeted medicine could have the potential to treat the cancer with dramatic effect.

Loxo Oncology has a promising portfolio of approved and investigational medicines, including:

LOXO-292, a first-in-class oral RET inhibitor that has been granted Breakthrough Therapy designation by the FDA for three indications, with an initial potential launch in 2020. LOXO-292 targets cancers with alterations to the rearranged during transfection (RET) kinase. RET fusions and mutations occur across multiple tumor types, including certain lung and thyroid cancers as well as a subset of other cancers.
LOXO-305, an oral BTK inhibitor currently in Phase 1/2. LOXO-305 targets cancers with alterations to the Bruton's tyrosine kinase (BTK), and is designed to address acquired resistance to currently available BTK inhibitors. BTK is a validated molecular target found across numerous B-cell leukemias and lymphomas.
Vitrakvi, a first-in-class oral TRK inhibitor developed and commercialized in collaboration with Bayer that was recently approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA). Vitrakvi is the first treatment that targets a specific genetic abnormality to receive a tumor-agnostic indication at the time of initial FDA approval.
LOXO-195, a follow-on TRK inhibitor also being studied by Loxo Oncology and Bayer for acquired resistance to TRK inhibition, with a potential launch in 2022.

Excel Developer @Sam Whitmore: Markets Live has been going for 10 years now. Although the archive is down, https://ftalphaville.ft.com/marketslive/2009-01-07/
Centrica PLC (CNA:LSE): Last: 130.95, down 6.35 (-4.62%), High: 135.30, Low: 129.45, Volume: 15.22m
BE11:46am

We downgrade Centrica to Hold, given we see material downside risk to 2019-20 earnings, borderline credit metrics and limited MTM benefits of higher commodity prices in the medium-term. With this, we see a timely disposal of Centrica's 20% nuclear stake as critical to protect its balance sheet against another potential hit. In the near-term, we also expect a weak FY18 update in February to weigh on the stock. Downgrade to Hold, with PT of 125p (nil TSR).

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Further EPS downgrades to come. With operational issues for its E&P and nuclear assets, suspension of UK capacity market payments, volatile commodity prices, high customer churn rates and SVT price cap, we estimate an 8% yoy decline in 2019 EPS for Centrica (vs. flat earnings profile previously). With this, we see 10% downside risk to 2019-20 consensus EPS.

Tighter credit metrics; limited capacity to absorb another hit. With materially lower 2018-20 earnings forecasts, we expect Centrica's adjusted operating cash flow to dip below the company's £2.1-2.3bn guidance range in 2018-19, and be at the lower end of the range in 2020. With this, we see borderline credit metrics for Centrica (average 2018-20 RCF/net debt at the key 25% threshold for its current BBB+ rating) and 12p DPS hanging by a thread. In a scenario where UK power and gas prices follow the trend of oil prices and fall a further 20%, we see 2019-20 cash DPS cover of below 1x (with 20% scrip) and a one notch credit rating downgrade as likely for Centrica.

BE11:47am

Nuclear disposal is critical for Centrica's balance sheet. With tight credit metrics and uncertainty around the UK capacity market, we see the timely disposal of Centrica's 20% nuclear stake as critical. We estimate that a c.£1bn valuation would be needed to reinforce Centrica's balance sheet and provide sufficient protection against a potential commodity-related shock.

A weak FY18 update ahead. With its 3Q18 trading update, Centrica has guided to FY18 EPS of 11.5p (-10% to consensus at the time, due to lower E&P production and nuclear output). We also anticipate further disappointment from Centrica's FY18 update in February. With UK residential gas volumes down 8% yoy over the last two months of 2018, we estimate this implies a 3% hit (-0.4p) to Centrica's FY18 EPS guidance.

15% cut to 2018-20 EPS forecasts. With a more pessimistic outlook for UK retail, lower commodity prices, lower E&P production and c.40% effective tax rate, we cut our 2018-20 EBIT and EPS forecasts by 8% and 15% respectively.

hornblower @ Penny, thks
BE11:51am

Which means doing Brexit probabilities. I apologise in advance.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Scenario 1: Some form of the withdrawal agreement accepted
Our UK strategists believe this scenario is still possible although the uncertainty is high. This could happen for example if opposition MPs abstain (c70% represent a pro-Brexit constituency); if dissenting govt. MPs strike a last minute deal; or if the deal returns to parliament after winning popular support in a referendum. In this scenario we would expect a sigh of relief for the UK economy and a small bounce for the names with nationalisation risk (SSE, NG, SVT, UU, PNN) due to the lower chances of a General Election. On a relative basis, National Grid might underperform (given USD earnings and likely sterling appreciation) while Pennon might outperform (given Viridor).

Scenarios 2, 3, 4: What if parliament does not accept the deal?
Broadly, we expect the other three scenarios would be seen as a defeat for the current government and Prime Minister, and so could increase the perceived risk of a General Election – bringing Labour's nationalisation plans back to the foreground. In a general election scenario, the nationalisation names might trade down to an EV/RAB discount, (to compensate risk of nationalisation at RAB). More generally, in a No Deal scenario with sterling depreciation, National Grid could outperform.

What about Centrica?
We previously saw Centrica as a good option in the UK, with no direct exposure to the nationalisation debate. But performance has disappointed; retail market dynamics have deteriorated; and we recently downgraded to Neutral (PT 135p). Centrica also has USD earnings, and might under-perform relatively in our Scenario 1. So those wishing to avoid nationalisation risk altogether could look to Europe (where e.g. Orsted, Enel, Naturgy have a more straightforward equity story) or to other UK defensive sectors.
